answers.answer: He needs to see an Endocrinologist to have his thyroid checked. The tests he needs to insist on are TSH, FT3, FT4 and antibodies. Tell him not to just check his TSH because he could be within normal range but still have thyroid problems. He needs all of the tests I mentioned.Did his Dr tell him to stay away from fatty and fried foods after he had his gallbladder removed? Those kinds of foods can aggravate the stomach if you have no gallbladder.How long ago did he have the surgery? It can take a little time for his liver enzymes to get back to normal.What does his heart rate get up to with the  tachycardia? An EKG can not show everything. If he thinks there might be a heart problem he could get more detailed tests, like a cath test.   Remar

question: My son is 41 years old.  He recenlty had his gall bladder out after several months of being told nothing was wrong with me.  since the surgery he has become progressively worse.  He suffers with pain in his abdomen and neck.  He has had many tests, some of which have told us that he has elevated bilirubin, elevated liver studies, a leaky heart valve, and abnormal heart beat.  He experiences heart attack like pain, but his ekg's show (with the exception of tachicardia) a normal heart.  He  has had two hyde a scans, one of which showed the abnormal gall bladder.  'The second was "normal".  He has been diagnosed with gastric enpuresis (?) which they say is secondary to his diabetes (which is under control).  He has now developed many lumps under the skin on all parts of his torso and his thyroid is enlarged.  No one can seem to find anything that is causing these symptoms but keep encouraging him to go to the ER when he has chest pain.  Any Ideas?  I swear I am not making any of this up.  He is so discouraged he was in tears today.  He is not a hypochondriac but was exposed to many chemicals during Desert Storm.  HELP!!
